Lack enough support: The claim lacks sufficient evidence or support from credible sources, as it is based on a viral WhatsApp message and not an official statement from the World Health Organisation (WHO).
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the viral message accurately represents the lockdown protocol of the World Health Organisation, without providing any verifiable proof.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that the World Health Organisation has stated that they do not have any protocols for lockdowns, as confirmed by a tweet from WHO South-East Asia.
Exaggerate: The claim may exaggerate the significance and authority of the viral message by suggesting that it is an official circular from WHO, even though it is not.
Falters at times: The claim falters in its credibility due to the poor English used in the viral message, which suggests that it is not an official communication from the World Health Organisation.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim does not consider alternative explanations for the origins of the viral message, such as it being based on media reports and a study from Cambridge University, rather than an official WHO protocol.
